Antioch, IL 60002

citations.narrative:
Over a two-day inspection, the inspectors observed that the two rabbits were handled in a manner that did not minimize
harm to the animal and the public.
On Friday, January 9th, the inspectors observed many children and adults petting and handling the rabbits without an
employee ensuring the safety of the animals and people involved. An attendant was standing outside the enclosure,
however the large crowd in between the attendant and the rabbits interfered with supervising. A child was bitten on the
hand by a rabbit when attempting to hand-feed the rabbit lettuce that had been placed on the floor of the enclosure.
Handling animals in this manner increases the risk of injury or harm to the animals and to the public.
Measures were taken to correct this after the inspection. Correct from this day forward (January 14, 2026) by ensuring
that during public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public.

Over two consecutive days the inspectors observed that several animals were exhibited for periods of time and under
conditions inconsistent with their good health and well-being. The inspectors observed the following:
- The sloth, "Stella", was exhibited for four consecutive hours on Friday, January 9th (4:00 PM – 8:00 PM), and a total of
6.5 hours on Saturday, January 10th (10:00 AM – 6:00 PM with a 1-hour scheduled break followed by a 30-minute
scheduled break). She was scheduled for another four-hour exhibition (10:00AM – 2:00 PM) on Sunday, January 11th.
The licensee stated that Stella got multiple smaller, unscheduled breaks throughout the day, which the inspectors were
unable to visually confirm due to the arrangement of the photo booth. However, sloths are nocturnal and sleep on average
15-20 hours during the day.
- “Stella” also did not have the opportunity to hang or perch from elevated furniture for the duration of the event. Stella had
furniture to rest in/on, and spent a long portion of the event holding onto her caretaker inside and outside the tented
exhibit area. However, sloth’s natural behavior is to live solitary in trees and spend most of their time hanging from a tree
branch or similar.
- The rabbits were in view of the public for the entirety of the inspection. The animals had a 45-minute break from public
handling (e.g. petting and holding) on Saturday, January 10th, but remained in view of and close to the public during this
break. Their temporary enclosures did not contain hide areas to avoid public eye. They were observed in the corner of the
enclosure, which can indicate an attempt to avoid public handling.
Exhibiting animals under conditions and time periods inconsistent with their natural wake-sleep cycles, natural behaviors,
and without opportunity to avoid public viewing, can affect their physical and psychological health.
Measures were taken to correct this for the remainder of the exhibition. Continue to correct this from this day forward
(January 14th, 2025) by exhibiting animals for periods of time and under conditions consistent with their good health and
well-being.

On Friday, January 9th, 2026, the floors of the temporary primary enclosures for the rabbits did not contain litter. The floor
consisted of soft rubber matting.
Litter provides a comfortable resting spot as well as an area to absorb excreta, which facilitates sanitary conditions.
The facility had corrected this unprompted on Saturday, January 10th, by providing a sufficient layer of straw on the
flooring. Continue to correct from this day forward (January 14th, 2026) by ensuring that litter shall be provided in all
primary enclosures having solid floors.

On Friday, January 9th, and Saturday, January 10th, the facility housed rabbits in the same enclosure as goats.
The animals were in two adjoining pens with a gate. However, during the exhibition hours, the gate remained open so that
the members of the public could freely walk between the two areas, allowing the animals to share a floor space. An
inspector witnessed a goat pass through the gate and enter the rabbits' side of the enclosure. After a period, an attendant
moved the goat back to the goat side of the enclosure, but did not shut the gate.
Sharing an enclosure with other animals can pose a health and safety risk for both rabbits and goats, such as bacterial
and parasitic diseases, or injury from interaction.
The facility corrected this for the remainder of the event on Saturday, January 10th, and Sunday, January 11th. Continue
to correct from this day forward, January 14th, 2026, by ensuring rabbits are not housed in the same primary enclosure
with any other species of animals.
This inspection was conducted at the Bald Eagle Days event at the QCCA Expo Center in Rock Island, IL. The exit
interview was conducted after the inspection with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Jessica Siegal-Willott n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
Over a two-day inspection, the inspectors observed that the two rabbits were handled in a manner that did not minimize 
harm to the animal and the public.  
 
On Friday, January 9th, the inspectors observed many children and adults petting and handling the rabbits without an 
employee ensuring the safety of the animals and people involved. An attendant was standing outside the enclosure, 
however the large crowd in between the attendant and the rabbits interfered with supervising. A child was bitten on the 
hand by a rabbit when attempting to hand-feed the rabbit lettuce that had been placed on the floor of the enclosure. 
 
Handling animals in this manner increases the risk of injury or harm to the animals and to the public. 
 
Measures were taken to correct this after the inspection. Correct from this day forward (January 14, 2026) by ensuring 
that during public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public. 
2.131(d)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
Over two consecutive days the inspectors observed that several animals were exhibited for periods of time and under 
conditions inconsistent with their good health and well-being. The inspectors observed the following: 
 
- The sloth, "Stella", was exhibited for four consecutive hours on Friday, January 9th (4:00 PM – 8:00 PM), and a total of 
6.5 hours on Saturday, January 10th (10:00 AM – 6:00 PM with a 1-hour scheduled break followed by a 30-minute 
scheduled break). She was scheduled for another four-hour exhibition (10:00AM – 2:00 PM) on Sunday, January 11th. 
The licensee stated that Stella got multiple smaller, unscheduled breaks throughout the day, which the inspectors were 
unable to visually confirm due to the arrangement of the photo booth. However, sloths are nocturnal and sleep on average 
15-20 hours during the day.  
 
- “Stella” also did not have the opportunity to hang or perch from elevated furniture for the duration of the event. Stella had 
furniture to rest in/on, and spent a long portion of the event holding onto her caretaker inside and outside the tented 
exhibit area. However, sloth’s natural behavior is to live solitary in trees and spend most of their time hanging from a tree 
branch or similar.

- The rabbits were in view of the public for the entirety of the inspection. The animals had a 45-minute break from public 
handling (e.g. petting and holding) on Saturday, January 10th, but remained in view of and close to the public during this 
break. Their temporary enclosures did not contain hide areas to avoid public eye. They were observed in the corner of the 
enclosure, which can indicate an attempt to avoid public handling.  
 
Exhibiting animals under conditions and time periods inconsistent with their natural wake-sleep cycles, natural behaviors, 
and without opportunity to avoid public viewing, can affect their physical and psychological health. 
 
Measures were taken to correct this for the remainder of the exhibition. Continue to correct this from this day forward 
(January 14th, 2025) by exhibiting animals for periods of time and under conditions consistent with their good health and 
well-being. 
3.53(a)(4) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
On Friday, January 9th, 2026, the floors of the temporary primary enclosures for the rabbits did not contain litter. The floor 
consisted of soft rubber matting.  
 
Litter provides a comfortable resting spot as well as an area to absorb excreta, which facilitates sanitary conditions.  
 
The facility had corrected this unprompted on Saturday, January 10th, by providing a sufficient layer of straw on the 
flooring. Continue to correct from this day forward (January 14th, 2026) by ensuring that litter shall be provided in all 
primary enclosures having solid floors. 
3.58(a) 
   
Classification and separation. 
On Friday, January 9th, and Saturday, January 10th, the facility housed rabbits in the same enclosure as goats.  
 
The animals were in two adjoining pens with a gate. However, during the exhibition hours, the gate remained open so that 
the members of the public could freely walk between the two areas, allowing the animals to share a floor space. An 
inspector witnessed a goat pass through the gate and enter the rabbits' side of the enclosure. After a period, an attendant 
moved the goat back to the goat side of the enclosure, but did not shut the gate. 
 
Sharing an enclosure with other animals can pose a health and safety risk for both rabbits and goats, such as bacterial 
and parasitic diseases, or injury from interaction.  
 
The facility corrected this for the remainder of the event on Saturday, January 10th, and Sunday, January 11th. Continue 
to correct from this day forward, January 14th, 2026, by ensuring rabbits are not housed in the same primary enclosure 
with any other species of animals.

This inspection was conducted at the Bald Eagle Days event at the QCCA Expo Center in Rock Island, IL. The exit 
interview was conducted after the inspection with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors:
